title: Centripetal force - sled on circular track

content.question: A sled slides along a vertical circular track of radius <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math>, as shown. There is negligible friction between the sled and the track. At the bottommost point of the track, the sled has speed <math alttext="v sub b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>b</mtext></msub></math>. Which of the following graphs best show the normal force exerted by the track on the sled at the bottommost point of the track as a function of <math alttext="v sub b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>b</mtext></msub></math>?

choices.label: The figure shows the graph of a line in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane, with the origin labeled O. The horizontal axis is labeled v sub b, and the vertical axis is labeled F sub N. The line begins at the origin and slants upward and to the right until it ends at a point high above the horizontal axis, and far to the right of the vertical axis.

The figure shows the graph of a line in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane, with the origin labeled O. The horizontal axis is labeled v sub b, and the vertical axis is labeled F sub N. The line begins just above the origin and slants upward and to the right until it ends at a point high above the horizontal axis, and far to the right of the vertical axis.

The figure shows the graph of a curve in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane, with the origin labeled O. The horizontal axis is labeled v sub b, and the vertical axis is labeled F sub N. The curve begins at the origin, moves gradually upward and to the right at first, and then much more steeply until it ends at a point high above and approximately halfway along the horizontal axis.
